title: Ukiyo-e: Actors with Snow, Moon, and Flowers
transcript:
Narrator: What follows is a conversation between curator Janice Katz and writer and editor at Teen
Vogue, Lucy Diavolo. Please note that on this stop they are speaking about a single painting on your left
that is part of a triptych.

Janice Katz: Okay. So this is interesting because a lot of the idea of picturing femininity comes from
men, and men actually playing female roles in the Kabuki theatre.

Janice Katz: This happens to be a portrait of an actor, a man playing a female role, very well-known for
playing female roles, but here he’s not shown as if he’s on stage. This actor is portrayed very much as a
beauty of a time with all the femininity and grace that you would find in depictions of women.

Lucy Diavolo: The feminine ideal, being something men were making up. <laughs>

Janice Katz: Mm-hm.

Lucy Diavolo: That feels so resonant--

Janice Katz: <laughs>

Lucy Diavolo: --throughout history, and then what you were saying too about Kabuki, playing by
Shakespeare rules--

Janice Katz: Right. <laughs>

Lucy Diavolo: --with who could play what parts, especially across genders. It’s fascinating then that this
person, this actor, is presented outside of that space. What resonates with me about that as, like, a trans
woman, is a space like Kabuki sounds so familiar to me to different spaces where this sort of gender
experimentation is not only accepted but even celebrated. The history is there to show it goes back
thousands of years.

Janice Katz: It looks like her lip on-- her bottom lip is green, right?
Lucy Diavolo: Mm-hm.

Janice Katz: And it is, because the makeup that was used is called Sasadio-beni [ph?], which is red, but
when you put it on thickly it turns iridescent green, and this is a very expensive pigment.

Lucy Diavolo: How expensive? <laughs>

Janice Katz: It’s super, super expensive.

Lucy Diavolo: Okay.

Janice Katz: It’s made from these flowers. You have to use a large amount of them in order to get that
rich, red color, and you see it in the garments too. They’re dyed a deep red. Usually you would look at
that and say, “Oh, my gosh. What a bright, vivid color.” Somebody who knows the cost would look at it
and say, “Oh, my gosh. What an expensive robe that is,” and you only see a little sliver of it.

Lucy Diavolo: It’s such, like, a fascinating choice to make, you know, like, putting your Gucci on under
your Target collection.

Janice Katz: <laughs>

Lucy Diavolo: That sort of, “You know how expensive this was,” mood around fashion is such a--
something we still see today, <laughs> I think.
